title: Záhorie Protected Landscape Area
text:
Záhorie Protected Landscape Area () is the first <a href="lowland">lowland</a> <a href="Protected%20areas%20of%20slovakia%23Protected%20Landscape%20Areas">protected landscape area</a> in <a href="Slovakia">Slovakia</a>. It is located in the non-administrative <a href="Z%C3%A1horie">Záhorie</a> Region in West Slovakia. The Landscape Area protects 275.22 km² (106.26 mi²) and is divided into two separate parts – western and north-eastern. The western part starts near the village of <a href="K%C3%BAty">Kúty</a> in the north, follows the borders between Slovakia and <a href="Austria">Austria</a> alongside the <a href="Morava%20%28river%29">Morava River</a> and ends near <a href="Stupava%2C%20Slovakia">Stupava</a> in the south. The north-eastern part is bordered by the <a href="Z%C3%A1horie%20%28military%20district%29">Military District of Záhorie</a> in the east and south.
Geography, geology and ecology.
The western part of the Landscape Area is formed by the <a href="Morava%20%28river%29">Morava River</a> and mainly consists of vast <a href="riparian%20zones">riparian zones</a> and <a href="floodplains">floodplains</a>. This area is well preserved because it had been a strictly prohibited border between the <a href="Eastern%20Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> and the <a href="Western%20Bloc">Western Bloc</a> for 40 years, known as the <a href="Iron%20Curtain">Iron Curtain</a>. The area contains the largest <a href="water-meadow">water-meadow</a>s in Slovakia. The riparian forests, mainly in <a href="Horn%C3%BD%20les">Horný les</a> and <a href="Doln%C3%BD%20les">Dolný les</a>, contain trees similar to the original <a href="old%20growth%20forests">old growth forests</a>. A vast network of <a href="Channel%20%28geography%29">channels</a>, <a href="wetland">wetland</a>s and small lakes is spread in the riparian zones and floodplains. These rich and dynamic geographical features bring an extensive variety of <a href="flora">flora</a> and <a href="fauna">fauna</a>. Plants are represented by, for example, large areas of "<a href="Clematis">Clematis integrifolia</a>". The water <a href="habitat">habitat</a> is dominantly occupied by animal groups such as <a href="crustaceans">crustaceans</a>, <a href="molluscs">molluscs</a>, <a href="fish">fish</a>, <a href="amphibians">amphibians</a> and a lot of species of <a href="Anseriformes">aquatic birds</a>. The <a href="European%20beaver">European beaver</a> returned to this area from Austria, where it was <a href="reintroduction">reintroduced</a> in the 1980s.
The north-eastern part contains sand deposited by <a href="aeolian%20processes">aeolian processes</a>, which create <a href="dunes">dunes</a>. Because of its location, this area is an important route for <a href="Bird%20migration">migrating birds</a>. The contrast between colder lower areas and warm sand dunes creates a bright variety of species. The warm and dry areas are home to the <a href="antlion">antlion</a> and <a href="hoopoe">hoopoe</a>. The fir forests are home to insect predators, which serve as a feeding ground for the <a href="European%20nightjar">European nightjar</a>, <a href="woodlark">woodlark</a> and <a href="bat">bat</a>s.
Tourism.
In the western part, the artificial <a href="levee">levee</a> alongside the Morava River and adjacent newly built biking trail contains boards and <a href="poster">poster</a>s informing about wildlife and is also popular with hikers. The north-eastern part contains biking and hiking trails, offering unique sand dunes. Biking trails are interconnected with others outside the Landscape Area.
See also.
<a href="Protected%20areas%20of%20Slovakia">Protected areas of Slovakia</a>
